awd_titl_txt: Investigation of Quantum Coherence and Correlated Dynamics Using Attosecond Spectroscopy
awd_abstract_narration:
Electron motion is fundamental to the natural and laboratory phenomena that govern our daily lives, examples being photosynthesis, chemical processes, electronic circuits, etc. Being elementary particles, electrons are extremely agile, and can move inside atoms, molecules and materials on the timescale of attoseconds, which is a billionth of a billionth of a second. To understand the functioning of physical, chemical and biological processes important to us, it is useful to be able to resolve and control the underlying fast electronic motion. Recently devised attosecond spectroscopy provides exactly such an opportunity, where attosecond duration light pulses can be used to strobe the dynamics of electrons. The researchers supported by this project will develop methods to study how electrons help to redistribute energy within molecules. Success along these directions could open up opportunities for direct control of chemical processes in complex molecules relevant for light harvesting and energy storage. The proposed program will therefore advance US scientific efforts in a frontier area of research, while training the next generation of scientists belonging to diverse backgrounds.

This project aims for detailed investigation of quantum coherence and correlated electronic and nuclear dynamics using ultrafast light pulses. These studies will focus on what transpires at the quantum level, in terms of interactions between electrons, couplings between electrons and nuclei, and between molecules and the environment. The natural timescale for the evolution of electronic superpositions is in the femtoseconds to attosecond regime, so these investigations will involve the application of attosecond to femtosecond x-ray, extreme ultraviolet, and infrared light pulses. The scientific objectives of the project are: (1) Investigation of correlated decay dynamics of molecular excited states, (2) Study of coherent charge migration and decoherence mechanisms, and (3) Implementation of new techniques to study charge directed reactivity. These objectives will be achieved while training graduate and undergraduate students in the field of attosecond spectroscopy. Velocity map imaging and attosecond transient absorption techniques will be used in the proposed work. The far-reaching objective is to build bridges between the field of physics, and those of chemistry, biology and material sciences, paving the way for control of a variety of electron driven processes. The project will also conduct outreach by involving undergraduates and the local community, and by creating advanced research opportunities for members of under-represented groups.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Understanding the coherent evolution of electrons in atoms, molecules, and materials is key to devising strategies for the quantum control of the fundamental constituents of matter. Being very light elementary particles, electrons move on fast timescales of attoseconds to femtoseconds, which is in the range of a millionth of a billionth of a second. To perform real-time investigation of electron dynamics, we used attosecond extreme ultraviolet pulse trains to create quantum superpositions of several excited states in atoms and molecules. These superpositions evolve in time while maintaining the phase relationships between constituent states, leading to coherent wavepacket motion. To resolve such dynamics, we employed time-delayed infrared light pulses, which act as a strobe that ionizes the electrons. We detected the interference between ionized electrons using techniques such as photoelectron interferometry and velocity map imaging, thus capturing the energy and angle of the electron waves emanating from the atom. The impressive time-resolution obtained in this technique comes as the expense of energy blurring due to quantum uncertainty principle. 

We developed a new approach of Raman electron interferometry to simultaneously achieve both temporal control and energy resolution in our analysis of electron spectra. Essentially, we separated the probing and detection steps, so that probing is conducting with femtosecond resolution, while the detection occurs on long timescales which yields the required energy resolution. Access to both time and energy domains allows better understanding and control the system. We applied this technique to study the autoionizing states that give us insight into the coherent evolution of a multi-electron system. Our experimental results showed excellent agreement with quantum simulations which provides insights into the light-matter interaction. This work opens the doors to study molecular wave packets with closely spaced energy levels, providing a powerful tool to trace the ultrafast correlated motion of electrons, analyze the constituents of the electronic wavepackets, and understand the decoherence mechanisms in complex systems. 

In another study, we conducted transient absorption studies to investigate electron relaxation in two-dimensional systems to understand electron-vibration couplings and timescales for the conversion of electronic energy to other modes. These studies are important for devising new ultrathin devices that can operate fast without generating excessive heat. We also developed new tools for attosecond spectroscopy extending from extreme ultraviolet to the soft-x-ray regime. 

An important outcome of this project was in training the next generation workforce in the frontier area of attosecond science. This project imparted valuable professional development opportunities to several graduate, undergraduate, and high school students. Participants in this project also conducted scientific outreach activities involving students from local schools, underrepresented minority groups, visitors, and local community. The far-reaching impacts of this project is in quantum control of electronic coherence and understanding of charge and energy redistribution dynamics in atoms, molecules, and materials - topics which essential to devising ultrafast technologies and finding new methods for light energy harvesting and storage.
